text: Saleh al-Jumai'e (b. 1939 Saweira, Iraq) is an Iraqi artist noted for his works his works that explore the notion of tracks left by ancient heritage. His works often integrate Arabic calligraphy in an abstract artwork. ==Life and career== Saleh al-Jumai'e was born in 1939 in Saweira, Iraq.Bahrani, Z. and Shabout, N.M., Modernism and Iraq, Miriam and Ira D. Wallach Art Gallery, Columbia University, New York, 2009, p.94 He was among the first generation of students to graduate from the new Academy of Fine Arts in 1962. He and his cohort were taught by the first generation of contemporary Iraqi artists including Hafidh al-Droubi and Jawad Saleem, who promoted the idea of integrating ancient heritage within abstract artworks. Before long, the younger artists, including Al-Jumaie rebelled against traditional art styles and wanted to explore the use of new materials and media such as collage, aluminum and mono-type.Pocock, C., "The Reason for the Project Art in Iraq Today", in: Azzawi, D. (ed.), Art in Iraq Today, Abu Dhabi, Skira and Meem, 2011, p. 101 In 1965, shortly after graduating, al-Jumai'e co-founded the artists' group known as the 'Innovationists'.Pocock, C., "The Reason for the Project: Art in Iraq Today", in: Azzawi, D. (ed.), Art in Iraq Today, Abu Dhabi, Skira and Meem, 2011, pp 94-101 This group, which was short-lived, lasting just four years, consisted of a younger artists including: Salim al- Dabbagh, Faik Husein and Ali Talib, who along with Al-Jumaie began using new media in highly experimental ways.Pocock, C., "The Reason for the Project Art in Iraq Today", in: Azzawi, D. (ed.), Art in Iraq Today, Abu Dhabi, Skira and Meem, 2011, p. 101 In 1965, he was nominated for a Ministry of Education scholarship which allowed him to study at the Californian College of Arts and Crafts in Oakland and graduated with a Bachelor of Fine Arts.Fragments from Ancient Books, 1986 Online:; American Friends of the Middle East, [Exhibition Notes], 1966, Online: Following his return to Baghdad, he co-founded another artists' group. The Al-Ru’yah al-Jadida ['New Vision Group'].Bahrani, Z. and Shabout, N.M., Modernism and Iraq, Miriam and Ira D. Wallach Art Gallery, Columbia University, New York, 2009, p.30 and p. 92 Founded in 1968, by al- Jumai'e along with artists Ismail Fatah Al Turk; Muhammed Muhr al-Din, Hashimi al-Samarchi, Rafa al-Nadiri and Dia Azzawi,Ghareeb, E.A. and Dougherty, B., Historical Dictionary of Iraq, Scarecrow Press, 2004, p. 174 the group represented a free art style where many artists believed that they needed to be true to their own era,Salīm, N., Iraq: Contemporary Art, Volume 1, Sartec, 1977, p. 7 and encouraged the idea of freedom of creativity within a framework of heritage.Sabrah,S.A. and Ali, M.," Iraqi Artwork Red List: A Partial List of the Artworks Missing from the National Museum of Modern Art, Baghdad, Iraq, 2010, pp 7-9 In 1979, he left Iraq for political reasons, and in 1981 he and his family settled in Almeda, California where he worked as a freelance graphic artist. ==Work== Al-Jumaie and his cohort including Amer al-Obaidi, Salman Abbas and Nida Kadhim became the group of artists that defined 1960s Iraqi art.Salīm, N., Iraq: Contemporary Art, Volume 1, Sartec, 1977, p. 173; Dabrowska,K. and Hann, G., Iraq Then and Now: A Guide to the Country and Its People, Bradt Travel Guides, 2008, p. 279; Dabrowska,K. and Hann, G. and Townsend Greaves, T. Iraq: The Ancient Sites and Iraqi Kurdistan, Bradt Travel Guides, 2015, pp 30-31 Although al-Jumaie is best remembered as a painter, he also designed posters and produced a number of book covers."Book Covers designed by Saleh Al-Jumaie," in Modern Art Iraq Archive, Item #793, Online: His early work features Arabic lettering, but over time the calligraphy became fainter. His interest in exploring new media and materials was maintained throughout his career. The art critic, Jabra Ibrahim Jabra wrote of the artist's capacity to combine ancient and modern as well as abstract and figurative styles: The idea of tracks left by tradition is a theme that Jumaie takes up in much of his work. For example, Pages from Old Books is a series of mixed media artworks that creates an illusion of surfaces on which fragments of script have been written.Collier, C., "Contemporary Arab Art: Modern Painters of the Arab World", Sheraton Magazine, vol 2, no. 5, p. 24 http://artiraq.org/maia/archive/files/sheraton-magazine- vol-2-no-5_69476ba92c.pdf The notion of traces is particularly evident in one of his best-known works, Bullet Trace (1967); a powerful work that deals with the shock of the six day war.Hann, F., Dabrowska, K. and Townsend-Greaves, R., Iraq: The ancient Sites and Iraqi Kurdistan, Bradt Travel Guides, 2015, p. 31 Examples of his work can be found in the National Gallery of Jordan permanent collection;Wiǧdān ʻAlī, Jordan National Gallery of Fine Arts, al- Matḥaf al- Waṭanī al-Urdunnī lil-Funūn al-Ǧamīla (ʻAmmān), 2005, p. 225 and p. 286 the Museum of Modern Art, Baghdad; The Municipality of Olsq; The Arab Monetary Fund, Abu Dhabi and The International Labor Organization, Geneva.
